Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Network Integration: Advancing UNH's High-Performance End-to-End Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of New Hampshire (UNH) is developing a Science DMZ, a computer network capable of operating at 100 Gigabits per second that connects scientists to external partners and allows research data and equipment to be accessed locally regardless of actual location. Capitalizing on the existing UNH LAN design and 750 miles of UNH leased dark fiber cyberinfrastructure in New Hampshire, this Science DMZ creates a 100-fold increase in bandwidth available to UNH researchers for exchanging research data with worldwide collaborators over Internet2. Data-intensive research areas participating in the initial UNH Science DMZ deployment include Atmospheric & Geospace Research, Civil Engineering & Structural Health Monitoring, Experimental Fluid Dynamics & Flow Physics, Genomics, Ocean Mapping & Visualization, and research into high performance networking
itself.

UNH's Science DMZ offers researchers the ability to move data from generating instruments to storage repositories in high-availability data centers across the campus, ensuring that data security, management, and accessibility are maintained for both local and remote research teams. Real-time remote equipment management and data transfers from sensor networks and satellite feeds are enabled by the UNH research network upgrades and offer greater opportunities for collaboration by researchers.

This project will spawn new methods of data sharing and collaboration, offering NH researchers the means to participate in solving the grand challenges facing science today - complex problems requiring multidisciplinary, large-scale approaches. The Science DMZ will be a model for expansion of "big-data" scientific data stores and real-time collaboration for all levels of student education and scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this NSF CC-NIE award, UNH designed and constructed a Science DMZ, which is a100Gbps science network connecting key research instruments to DYNES, a high speed data transfer node (DTN), and other multi-gigabit pathways. This Science DMZ, named the UNH ScienceNet, was the collaborative effort of researchers and technologists in a large variety of disciplines. The goal of ScienceNet is to allow researchers in UNH campus buildings and those off-campus to collaborate on key research involving UNH. Capitalizing on the existing UNH LAN design, the ScienceNet offers researchers the ability to operate their research instruments across a large network pathway between data generating instruments and data storage repositories in the Research Computing and Information Technology data centers across campus, ensuring that data security, management and accessibility are maintained for the research teams local to and away from UNH.

The ScienceNet offers real-time remote equipment management and data transfers from sensor networks and satellite feeds to be delivered directly to research facilities rather than reviewed post-incident through the physical mailing of data storage devices and memory sticks. UNH is a node on Internet2’s NSF MRI-funded DYNES network. As part of this network, UNH researchers have the ability to safely, quickly and dynamically move research data from one institution to another through the DYNES instrument as well as through DTNs on the ScienceNet.

The ScienceNet is a new paradigm in network design as there is no firewall in the network pathway, but a variety of new security techniques within the ScienceNet assure that equipment and data remain protected while being available to research users. UNH’s perfSONAR equipment, also deployed and enhanced during this award, assists researchers on and off the UNH campus to view the network changes that occur with time, and offers new insight into the traffic patterns that cause network degradation and inhibit research from progressing. UNH’s leadership in the worldwide deployment of IPv6 and our new investments in InCommon Federation and eduroam enables local and remote research partners to access instruments, high-performance computing nodes, and data storage without the need to travel or ship valuable research data across geographic boundaries.

Through the use of perfSONAR and other software testing tools, we have performed a battery of tests to move a standard data file rom one location to another, varying the size of the data file, the source and destination addresses at UNH and elsewhere, and the application and protocol being used to transfer the data on the ScienceNet. We have also moved live data from two sites, and improved data throughput for researchers by a factor of up to 20.

Intellectual Merit: This project is a key component in a comprehensive vision to bring research collaboration to the next level of capability and effectiveness for the UNH research community. The acquisition of 100Gb networking equipment alone is not the change to be instituted at UNH. Rather, within the context of the existing and proposed research on campus, in NH and around the world, the completion of the ScienceNet has had an immediate and transformative impact on the five representative science scenario areas that we highlighted in this grant award: Atmospheric and Geospace Research,Civil Engineering & Structural Health Monitoring, Experimental Fluid Dynamics and Flow Physics,Genomics and Molecular & Comparative Endocrinology, and Ocean Mapping & Visualization. These representative areas, and others, have already begun to design their future research questions on the leveraged used of the UNH ScienceNet, making them more competitive for future research funds and enhancing their time to discovery for current and future research.
